Binjgb and simplicity

I've wanted to work on an emulator for a long time, probably since I first saw nesticle in high school. Last year I was looking for a new project to spend some time on, and started on binjgb, a gameboy emulator.

For the longest time, it was written as a single C file. My goal was to keep it as simple as possible, which meant I tried to avoid any superfluous code structure. This is especially prevalent in C, since it doesn't really provide you with many tools for compressing code and handling abstractions.

What do I mean by "superfluous code structure"? After I had binjgb in a mostly working state, I started looking at other gameboy emulators. It turns out that a lot of people use it as an "intro to emulator development", just like I did!

But a lot of the code I saw would do stuff like this:

class Instruction {
 public:
  virtual ~Instruction() {}
  virtual void Execute(Emulator&) = 0;
};

class LoadInstruction : public Instruction {
 public:
  LoadInstruction(Register src, Register dst) : src(src), dst(dst) {}

  virtual void Execute(Emulator& emulator) {
    emulator.reg(dst) = emulator.reg(src);
  }

  virtual void Print(Output& out) {
    out << "ld " << dst.name() << ", " << src.name();
  }

  Register src;
  Register dst;
};

LoadInstruction Op40(Register::B(), Register::B());
LoadInstruction Op41(Register::B(), Register::C());
LoadInstruction Op42(Register::B(), Register::D());
...

Where I tried to keep code like this as minimal as possible:

#define REG(R) e->state.reg.R

#define LD_R_R(RD, RS) REG(RD) = REG(RS)

  static void execute_instruction(Emulator* e) {
    ...
    // Instruction dispatch.
    switch (opcode) {
      ...
      case 0x40: LD_R_R(B, B);
      case 0x41: LD_R_R(B, C);
      case 0x42: LD_R_R(B, D);
      ...

As you can see, readability suffers. But in my opinion, dense straightforward C code is easier to read than sparse sprawling C++ code.

There are many other examples I could show here, but I think I may leave that for another blog post.

Canvas2D

When I wrote the initial renderer for binjgb on the web, I used canvas2D. It's simple and pretty easy to use. First, you need to create a canvas element:

var $ = document.querySelector.bind(document);
var canvasEl = $('canvas');

Then get the 2D rendering context:

this.ctx = el.getContext('2d');
